title: 110_s3323
content: The "Weatherization, Assistance, and Relief for Middle-Income Households Act of 2008" or the "WARM Act of 2008" appropriates $1,265,000,000 for low-income home energy assistance for fiscal year 2008. The Weatherization Assistance Program for Low-Income Persons is appropriated $523,000,000 for fiscal year 2008. Additionally, a credit for home heating oil expenditures is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a credit for home heating oil expenditures for individuals, allowing a credit of 50% of qualified expenditures, up to $1,000 ($2,000 for joint returns). The credit is subject to limitations based on adjusted gross income, reducing by 10% (20% for joint returns) for income exceeding $60,000 ($90,000 for joint returns). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a credit for home heating oil expenditures for individuals, allowing a credit of 50% of qualified expenditures, up to $1,000 ($2,000 for joint returns). The credit is subject to limitations based on adjusted gross income, reducing by 10% (20% for joint returns) for income exceeding $60,000 ($90,000 for joint returns). Qualified home heating oil expenditures are defined as purchases made for heating a dwelling unit or water in the US as a residence between June 1, 2008, and January 1, 2009. Amendments are made to sections 24, 25, and 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including sections 23, 25D, 26, 904, and 1400C, by inserting references to section 25E. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of chapter 1. SEC. 5. Denial of deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code denies deductions for major integrated oil companies involved in the production, refining, processing, transportation, or distribution of oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code denies deductions for major integrated oil companies involved in the production, refining, processing, transportation, or distribution of oil, gas, or primary products, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF DETERMINATION OF FOREIGN OIL AND GAS EXTRACTION INCOME. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 clarifies the determination of foreign oil and gas extraction income by defining a "fair market value event" for minerals before their fair market value is established through a transfer. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 clarifies the determination of foreign oil and gas extraction income by defining a "fair market value event" for minerals before their fair market value is established through a transfer, which must be an arm's length transaction with unrelated parties or at a location where fair market value is readily ascertainable. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines terms related to foreign oil and gas extraction taxes, income, and related income. Subparagraph (C) of section 907(c)(1) is also amended. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions related to transportation of minerals or primary products. The amendments will apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
